channel.title: MorningBrew as a feed
channel.description: This is a feed of recent MorningBrew articles published by Huginn

item.title: Apple, Spotify, and TikTok Release Their Year-End-Roundups
item.description: the global pandemic simulator Plague Inc. came in at No. 2 on the paid gaming charts. Spotify. App Store: Unsurprisingly, Zoom was the most downloaded free app of the year, with TikTok and Disney+ following closely behind.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: This Year’s Largest Acquisition? It’s Not What You Think
item.description: Bottom line: The former NYC mayor and memelord’s namesake company still towers over the financial data market.   Intercontinental Exchange, LSE rival and owner of the NYSE, has bought both mortgage finance tech platform Ellie Mae and data provider Interactive Data in the past few years.
item.author: Eliza Carter

item.title: Discovery Inc. Launches Streaming Service
item.description: It’s also partnering with Verizon to give 55 million customers one year of Discovery+ for free, a similar strategy to the Disney+ debut. It’s going big Discovery is offering 55,000 episodes from 2,500 different shows upon launch, the most content of any new streaming service.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: Coronavirus Aid: Democratic Leaders Back Compromise Bill
item.description: But there’s been some movement. Democratic Sen. Mark Warner told NBC that failing to pass a relief bill before Congress breaks for the holidays would be “stupidity on steroids.” Bottom line: Momentum has been building in the past few days, but time is extremely running out.
item.author: Eliza Carter

item.title: E-Commerce Boom Strains Delivery Networks
item.description: Follow the money  The investors with the biggest pockets are making bets on the physical infrastructure that powers e-commerce: warehouses.      Bottom line: With consumers feeling more comfortable shopping online and companies rapidly expanding their e-commerce infrastructure, the retail industry has been catapulted years into the future by the pandemic.   Shopify, a platform that’s home to 1+ million merchants, reported that Black Friday sales increased 75% annually to $2.4 billion, per Retail Brew. U.S. store visits dropped more than 50% on Black Friday from last year.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Sales for Beginners: The Best Articles and Expert Resources
item.description: Sales during “unprecedented” times   Giphy How Morning Brew’s Head of Brand Partnerships, Jason Schulweis, turned the pandemic into an opportunity  Eight big ways B2B sales changed A four-step guide for rethinking your sales approach  An in-depth white paper on how sales can adapt to the pandemic How to sell virtually, from Deloitte Five 2020 sales strategies from Entrepreneur 3.     What you will find: Insightful case studies, videos, articles, and more that people in the industry actually use to make them better professionals. How to stay up to date Read the LinkedIn Sales Blog SalesHacker is a great site for content and community 25 sales podcasts to choose from Read SocialMedia. Courses and certifications LinkedIn Sales Academy IBM’s Global Sales School This back-to-basics YouTube course Speakeasy’s virtual programming More marketing-tied, but useful for sales: IAB’s courses The art and science of sales enablement, by Roderick Jefferson 10.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Coronavirus Aid: Democratic Leaders Back Compromise Bill
item.description: But there’s been a development. Democratic Sen. Mark Warner told NBC that failing to pass a relief bill before Congress breaks for the holidays would be “stupidity on steroids.” Republican leadership wants a $550 billion package, Dems have favored one closer to $2 trillion.
item.author: Eliza Carter

item.title: This Year’s Largest Acquisition? It’s Not What You Think
item.description: Bottom line: The former NYC mayor and memelord’s namesake company still towers over the financial data market.   Intercontinental Exchange, LSE rival and owner of the NYSE, has bought both mortgage finance tech platform Ellie Mae and data provider Interactive Data in the past few years.
item.author: Eliza Carter

item.title: Apple, Spotify, and TikTok Release Their Year-End-Roundups
item.description: the global pandemic simulator Plague Inc. came in at No. 2 on the paid gaming charts. Spotify. App Store: Unsurprisingly, Zoom was the most downloaded free app of the year, and TikTok and Disney+ rounded out the top three.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: Discovery Inc. Launches Streaming Service
item.description: It’s also partnering with Verizon to give 55 million customers one year of Discovery+ for free, a similar strategy to the Disney+ debut. It’s going big Discovery is offering 55,000 episodes from 2,500 different shows upon launch, the most content of any new streaming service.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: E-Commerce Boom Strains Delivery Networks
item.description: Follow the money  The investors with the biggest pockets are making bets on the physical infrastructure that powers e-commerce: warehouses.      Bottom line: With consumers feeling more comfortable shopping online and companies rapidly expanding their e-commerce infrastructure, the retail industry has been catapulted years into the future by the pandemic.   Shopify, a platform that’s home to 1+ million merchants, reported that Black Friday sales increased 75% annually to $2.4 billion, per Retail Brew. U.S. store visits dropped more than 50% on Black Friday from last year.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: The McRib Returns to McDonald’s in Nationwide Rollout
item.description: + Did you know: Germany is the only country that's served the McRib all year round.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Startups in Micro Mobility, Freight Tech, and Customer Engagement, Announce Deals
item.description: It's one of many well-funded companies looking to disrupt the—how do we put this kindly—mature freight sector.   Scale AI, which yesterday raised $155 million at a monster valuation of $3.5 billion, gives companies the behind-the-scenes tools to help them actually put AI to work.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Nasdaq Proposes Board Diversity Requirements
item.description: From 2010–2018, seats held by Black directors increased just one percentage point to 9%. The Nasdaq would be the first major exchange to impose such requirements, but it's not alone in pushing for board diversity.    Over three-quarters of Nasdaq-listed companies can't meet that benchmark today.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: CDC Vaccine Panel Votes to Prioritize Healthcare Workers, Long Term Care Residents
item.description: The vaccine scene: Pfizer and Moderna have requested emergency use authorization for their Covid-19 vaccines. if CDC Director Robert Redfield approves ACIP's decision, this guidance will be sent to the states. What they decided: Phase 1 of Phase 1 is *drumroll please* healthcare personnel and long-term care facility (LTCF) residents. Not a simple decision.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Why SaaS Giant Salesforce Bought Slack
item.description: Zoom out: Salesforce and Slack have a common, four-paned enemy: Microsoft.   For Salesforce: Slack will join analytics company Tableau and cloud provider Vlocity in Salesforce's growing stable of business services offerings. Salesforce has been buying up enterprise-oriented companies in a bid to fulfill every workplace need outside of book club—and Slack is Salesforce's biggest purchase to date.   No need to worry about your favorite gossip channel disappearing; the WaPo writes that Slack's impressive brand loyalty will likely keep Salesforce from meddling too much in the app you know and love/dread.
item.author: Eliza Carter

item.title: Nasdaq Proposes Board Diversity Requirements
item.description: The Nasdaq would be the first major exchange to impose such requirements, but it's not alone in pushing for board diversity.    Over three-quarters of Nasdaq-listed companies can't meet that benchmark today. In 2018, women held just 22% of Fortune 500 board seats. Publicly disclose diversity statistics about their boards of directors.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: CDC Vaccine Panel Votes to Prioritize Healthcare Workers, Long Term Care Residents
item.description: Phase 1 of Phase 1 is *drumroll please* healthcare personnel and long-term care facility (LTCF) residents. The vaccine scene: Pfizer and Moderna have requested emergency use authorization for their Covid-19 vaccines.      Looking ahead...   The next round of Phase 1 will include essential workers, people with underlying health conditions, and adults 65+.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: The McRib Returns to McDonald’s in Nationwide Rollout
item.description: + Did you know: Germany is the only country that's served the McRib all year-round. The famous McRib returns to McDonald's menus today.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: It Went Down in the DMs
item.description: Zoom out: Salesforce and Slack have a common, four-paned enemy: Microsoft.   For Salesforce: Slack will join analytics company Tableau and cloud provider Vlocity in Salesforce's growing stable of business services offerings. Salesforce has been buying up enterprise-oriented companies in a bid to fulfill every workplace need outside of book club—but Slack is Salesforce's biggest purchase to date.   No need to worry about your favorite gossip channel disappearing; the WaPo writes that Slack's impressive brand loyalty will likely keep Salesforce from meddling too much in the app you know and love/dread.
item.author: Eliza Carter

item.title: Startups in Micro Mobility, Freight Tech, and Customer Engagement, Announce Deals
item.description: It's one of many well-funded companies looking to disrupt the—how do we put this kindly—mature freight sector.     Micromobility: Voi, a Swedish scooter rental startup, raised $160 million to help it expand in Europe. With more consumers interacting with brands over the internet, Sinch is the top-performing stock on the Stoxx Europe 600 index this year.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Under Armour and Steph Curry Launch Curry Brand
item.description: Zoom out: Even with Steph's marketing chops, Curry Brand alone probably won't be able to right Under Armour's ship. Nike's powerful Jordan Brand accounts for just ~9% of the company's overall revenue.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: Facebook to Buy CRM Startup Kustomer for $1B+
item.description: Why Facebook wants in: Kustomer rounds out a growing suite of services Facebook offers to the millions of businesses that use its platforms.   buying promising startups and squashing competition. Over 175 million people chat up businesses on WhatsApp each day.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: GM Pulls out of Deal With Nikola Corporation
item.description: The nowstory: GM and Nikola are entering into a non-binding "potential agreement" that scraps the equity stake and Badger trucks.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: Stocks, Crypto Post Record-Setting Month
item.description: Non-cryptocurrency: The dollar had its worst month since July, which is a sign investors stayed away from the safe haven asset and piled into riskier bets.   It's not totally surprising. Analysts point to greater commitments from big finance players—like PayPal and Square—for driving last month's 40% rally.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Biden Announces Economic Nominations and Appointments
item.description: Cecilia Rouse, dean of Princeton's School of Public and International Affairs, was nominated as chair.   Confirming recent reports, former Fed Chair Janet Yellen was nominated to become the first woman to head the Treasury.   Council of Economic Advisors: Think of it as the president's personal econ think tank, responsible for crafting policy and economic forecasting. Looking ahead…with a slowing recovery, worsening pandemic, and one month until ~12 million U.S. workers lose federal unemployment benefits, Biden's team will face the economic equivalent of Alabama in Week 1.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: GM Pulls out of Deal With Nikola Corporation
item.description: The nowstory: GM and Nikola are entering into a non-binding "potential agreement" that scraps the equity stake and Badger trucks.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: Biden Announces Economic Nominations and Appointments
item.description: Cecilia Rouse, dean of Princeton's School of Public and International Affairs, was nominated as chair.   Confirming recent reports, former Fed Chair Janet Yellen was nominated to become the first woman to head the Treasury.   Council of Economic Advisors: Think of it as the president's personal econ think tank, responsible for crafting policy and economic forecasting. She'd be the first woman of color to head the OMB, but of all Biden's early nominees, she may face the tightest confirmation battle.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Facebook to Buy CRM Startup Kustomer for $1B+
item.description: Why Facebook wants in: Kustomer rounds out a growing suite of services Facebook offers to the millions of businesses that use its platforms.   buying promising startups and squashing competition. Over 175 million people chat up businesses on WhatsApp each day.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Under Armour and Steph Curry Launch Curry Brand
item.description: Zoom out: As effective as Steph is as a marketer, Curry Brand alone probably won't be able to right Under Armour's ship. Even Nike's powerful Jordan Brand accounts for just ~9% of the company's overall revenue.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: Stocks, Crypto Post Record-Setting Month
item.description: Small cap stocks, Wall Street verbiage for smaller companies that are publicly traded, had their best month ever—up 19%.     Non-cryptocurrency: The dollar had its worst month since July, which is a sign investors stayed away from the safe haven asset and piled into riskier bets.   It's not totally surprising.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: The Week Ahead: November 30
item.description: Everything else:  Tuesday is the first day of December.    Earnings: Zoom will report Q3 financials today, Salesforce (following rumors it's in talks to acquire Slack) is up Tuesday, and recently IPOed Snowflake will report Wednesday.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: EU, UK Have Just 1 Month Left to Make Brexit Deal
item.description: With just one month left to reach a deal protecting ~$1 trillion worth of trade between the EU and UK, this is shaping up to be a critical week for Brexit negotiations.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: NYC to Reopen Schools Next Week
item.description: Next week, NYC will begin reopening preschools, kindergartens, and elementary schools, with middle and high schools to follow later, Mayor Bill de Blasio's office announced yesterday.   Leaders everywhere are wrestling with this Without federal guidance, the decision to open schools falls on state and local officials.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Black Friday? More Like Cyber Friday.
item.description: Shopping on U.S. retail websites, however, rose 22% over last year to $9 billion, according to Adobe Analytics.   And today is Cyber Monday.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Remembering Tony Hsieh, Former Zappos CEO
item.description: Hsieh took over and built an e-comm shoe colossus.   ShoeSite. Hsieh then started a fund and invested in the online shoe seller Zappos (then known as ShoeSite.   Quick bio In 1995, Hsieh (pronounced "shay") cofounded the internet ad company LinkExchange with a fellow Harvard alum. Nine years later...   more than $1 billion. At Zappos, he installed a self-management system called "Holacracy," which eliminated most traditional corporate hierarchy and allowed anyone to set meeting agendas.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: NYC to Reopen Schools Next Week
item.description: Next week, NYC will begin reopening preschools, kindergartens, and elementary schools, with middle and high schools to follow later, Mayor Bill de Blasio's office announced yesterday.   Leaders everywhere are wrestling with this Without federal guidance, the decision to open schools falls on state and local officials.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Remembering Tony Hsieh, Former Zappos CEO
item.description: Hsieh took over and built an e-comm shoe colossus.   ShoeSite. Hsieh then started a fund and invested in the online shoe seller Zappos (then known as ShoeSite.   Quick bio In 1995, Hsieh (pronounced "shay") cofounded the internet ad company LinkExchange with a fellow Harvard alum. Nine years later...   more than $1 billion. At Zappos, he installed a self-management system called "Holacracy," which eliminated most traditional corporate hierarchy and allowed anyone to set meeting agendas.
item.author: Neal Freyman
